title: 110_s863
content: The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2007" enhances penalties for fraud related to major disaster or emergency benefits by adding a new section to the United States Code. This section outlines actions that constitute fraud, such as falsifying information or making false statements in connection with benefits authorized for disasters or emergencies. Individuals involved in the authorization, transportation, transmission, transfer, disbursement, or payment of benefits related to major disaster or emergency declarations may face fines, imprisonment up to 30 years, or both. This applies to instances affecting interstate or foreign commerce. Individuals involved in the authorization, transportation, transmission, transfer, disbursement, or payment of benefits related to major disaster or emergency declarations may face fines, imprisonment up to 30 years, or both if the benefit is transported in the mail, involves interstate or foreign commerce, or is a record, voucher, payment, money, or thing of value of the United States or its agencies. SEC. 3 and SEC. 4 of the amendment increase criminal penalties for engaging in wire, radio, television, and mail fraud during and in relation to a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. The penalties apply to any benefit authorized, transported, transmitted, transferred, disbursed, or paid in connection with such disasters or emergencies. The amendment increases penalties for fraud offenses related to a presidentially declared disaster or emergency. The Sentencing Commission is directed to amend guidelines for increased penalties for fraud or theft offenses in connection with a major disaster declaration. The Sentencing Commission is required to amend guidelines for increased penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to a presidentially declared disaster or emergency. They must also submit an explanation of their actions to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees. The Sentencing Commission must amend guidelines for increased penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to a presidentially declared disaster or emergency. The Commission must also ensure consistency with other directives, account for circumstances that may justify exceptions, make necessary changes to sentencing guidelines, and meet the purposes of sentencing as outlined in the law. The guidelines or amendments must be promulgated within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. The Sentencing Commission must amend guidelines for increased penalties related to fraud or theft offenses in a presidentially declared disaster or emergency, in accordance with section 21(a) of the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987.
